lg.l: England! England! bonnie England!
Here across the Southern sea,
Sitting in the woods primeval,
Fondly now I think of thee.

Mighty birchesBirches. Likely a reference to species of beech, which were originally mistaken for a species of birch, and predominated in hilly and mountainous forests, especially in the South Island. all around me
And majestic pine-trees stand,
And a vast totaraTotara. Totara is the largest known species of podocarp. yonder
Towers like a monarch grand;
And a thousand branches quiver
In the soft and balmy air,
And the murmur of the river
Mingles into music rare.
All among the broadleaf bushes
Flocks of bright canariesCanaries. Mōhua, or yellowhead, once one of the most common birds in the South Island and known in the nineteenth century as the “bush canary.” wing,
And the tooiesTooies. Tui, A species of bird known for its melodious song. in the pine trees
Sweet among the branches sing,
Loud the screaming of the ka-kaKa-ka. Kaka, a large, brown, forest-dwelling parrot.
Rings upon the startled ear,
And the little love-birdsLove-birds. The reference is unclear. whistle
Gaily in the foliage near,

ParroquetsParroquets. Kākāriki, or the New Zealand parakeet, is predominantly bright green, with different species distinguished by coloured areas on their heads: the poem invokes the red-crowned and yellow-crowned species. in green and crimson,
Parroquets with crowns of gold,
Flitting softly, and the robinRobin. Kakaruwai, or the South Island robin.
Hops about me bright and bold,
And the little fairy fantailsFantails. Pīwakawaka, or the fantail, is a gregarious and acrobatic bird that feeds on insects.
Light upon me as I lie,
And about me in the sunbeams
Swift pursue the darting fly;
Feather-like the graceful fern-tree
Spreads its frondage overhead,
And the fuschia-treesFuschia-trees. Kōtukutuku, or the fuchsia tree, is considered the world’s largest species of fuchsia. around me
Thick their crimson blossoms shed;
And the busy bees are droning
Sweetly on the spicy air,
Oh this world is very lovely!
This New Zealand very fair!
Yet O England! bonnie England!
All my thoughts are now of thee,
And this beautiful New Zealand
Is not half so dear to me;
Tho’ it were a very Eden
Yet a stranger here I roam,
And my heart with fondest yearning
Sighs for England and for home.
Tho’ these woods were ever ringing
With the sweetest notes of earth,
More, to me, a robin singing
In an apple-tree were worth;
E’en an humble sparrow’s chatter,
More should please my longing ear,
Than the song of all the songsters
That awake the echoes here.
Grand is this primeval forest,
Yet I’d give it all to look
On an English elm, and listen
To the cawing o’ the rook.
England! England! bonnie England!
Let me see thy rock-bound shore!
Let me tread thy hills and valleys,
And thy daisied fields once more!
And tho’ this should be denied me,
Lovely land that gave me birth,
Let my sleeping ashes mingle
Fondly, with thy sacred earth!
Then—when springing daisies cluster
O’er the turf, above my breast,—
With thine arms about me, sweetly
As an infant I shall rest.
